The verdict triggered alarm , with some saying that science itself had been put on trial . On Monday an appeals court cleared the group of the manslaughter charges . Judge Fabrizia Ida Francabandera ruled that there was no case to answer . \" The credibility of Italy 's community has been restored ,\" said Stefano Gresta , the president of the National Institute of Geophysics and Volcanology . The seven men - all leading scientists or disaster experts - had been members of a committee convened in L'Aquila in March 2009 following a series of tremors in the region . Days after they met , a 6.3 magnitude quake struck the town in the middle of the night . of L'Aquila's buildings were destroyed , and some locals blamed the disaster committee for providing advice . Prosecutors in the trial said the experts had offered reassuring information to residents . According to Reuters , they noted that one committee member had said there was \" no danger \" from the tremors . Following the verdicts , than 5,000 scientists signed an letter to President Giorgio Napolitano in support of the experts . argued that the convictions represented a misunderstanding of earthquake science . Monday 's decision to overturn the verdicts came after a appeal process . The prosecution can seek to have the verdicts reinstated via a court .", "US experts found B3 , known as nicotinamide , boosts the ability of cells to kill Staphylococcus bacteria . B3 increases the numbers and efficacy of neutrophils , blood cells that can kill and eat bugs . The study , in the Journal of Clinical Investigation , could lead to a \" change in treatment \" , a UK expert said . B3 was tested on infections , as the MRSA ( Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus ) . infections are found in hospitals and nursing homes , but are on the rise in prisons , the military and among athletes . The scientists used doses of B3 - than that obtained from sources - in their tests , carried out both on animals and on blood . And the researchers say there is no evidence that B3 or supplements could prevent or treat infections . The researchers say B3 appears to be to \" turn on \" genes , boosting the cells' killing power . Prof Adrian Gombart , of Oregon State University 's Linus Pauling Institute , who worked on the research , said : \" This is , although we need to do studies . \" Antibiotics are wonder drugs , but they face increasing problems with resistance by types of bacteria , Staphylococcus aureus . \" This could give us a way to treat Staph infections that can be , and might be used in combination with antibiotics . \" It 's a way to tap into the power of the system and stimulate it to provide a and response . \" Prof Mark Enright , of the University of Bath , said : \" Neutrophils are the line against infections in the blood and the use of nicotinamide seems at this dose to use in patients as it is licensed for use . \" This could cause a change in treatment for infections alongside antibiotics to help bolster patients system . \" I would like to see in trials but cannot see this could be used in infected patients . \"", "The review into 22 abuse cases in Northern Ireland criticised the authorities for doing . The people went a number of times over a period while being looked after in the care system . The Police Service of Northern Ireland ( PSNI ) said it has made policy changes aimed at keeping children . In September 2013 , the PSNI said it had begun a investigation into the exploitation of children and people who had gone from care in Northern Ireland . Officers said they had identified 22 people , aged between 13 and 18 , who may have been exploited . The PSNI investigation was known was Operation Owl . Thursday 's report , examining the PSNI response , has been published by the Safeguarding Board for Northern Ireland . It said PSNI officers were in locating the teenagers and returning them to the care system . , it found that they failed to examine the extent of the child exploitation taking place and their attempts to find and stop the abusers was - in the words of the review - \" and \" . While there is praise for the help offered by some staff from care homes , Stormont 's Health Minister Simon Hamilton said that the report shows support was given to protect the teenagers from harm or the risk of harm . He said the review had identified \" a gap \" in knowledge about perpetrators of child exploitation . The head of the PSNI 's Public Protection Branch , Det Ch Supt George Clarke said that following Operation Owl , the PSNI has \" implemented a number of changes in our approach to handling this issue to ensure we are doing everything we can to keep children and people \" . \" , in April of this year , the PSNI formed the Public Protection Branch which is for policy and practice in relation to a number of areas including child exploitation . \" The structures enable us to work with our partner agencies in a way than to ensure protection and safeguarding for children and people . \" The office said the PSNI has revised its Missing Persons Protocol , a policy with the health and care authorities . \" This protocol is designed to support safeguarding responses by the PSNI and services in respect of children who run or go from their homes or care placements and builds upon developments in our knowledge and experience ,\" Mr Clarke added . year , a review into the issue concluded that exploitation was a growing threat to people in Northern Ireland . Those involved in crimes as charging rates for loans or extortion saw three times the boost of those who committed crimes . But , on , the 712 left education a year than men of a age in their neighbourhoods . \" careers are known to start and are to be interwoven with schooling choices ,\" the study says . Lead researcher Prof Giovanni Mastrobuoni said education tended to have a effect against getting involved with crime , but he added : \" It is that if you decide to be a criminal it 's to be a one . \" The study says : \" returns to education exist in but in the activities that imply a degree of complexity ,\" \" Mobster returns ( in terms of income ) to a year of schooling are around 7.5 to 8.5 % , compared to 9-10 % for the neighbour sample . \" , for mobsters who , according to the Federal Bureau of Narcotics records , were involved in crimes that require running an business ( ie racketeering , loan sharking , bootlegging et cetera ) we found returns to education that are three times as for those who are involved in crimes ( ie robberies , murders et cetera ).\"", "Wigan have paid \" in excess of \u00a3 200,000 \" for Tomkins , who they sold to New Zealand Warriors for a reported world record fee of \u00a3 700,000 in 2013 . Lots of people living tend to wear facemasks to help to filter out the pollution . architect Stefano Boeri came up with the idea of creating buildings which are of plants , to help fight pollution . These two buildings will be home to than 1,000 trees and 2,500 shrubs and bushes which should absorb the pollution in the air and help to filter it and make it . The buildings will be built in the city of Nanjing , and should be finished by 2018 . The tower will be a hotel , while the one will be home to a museum , offices and an architecture school . The buildings are the of their kind in Asia , but will join two buildings like them , from Italy and Switzerland . The architect has plans to build buildings in cities like Chongqing , Shijiazhuang , Liuzhou , Guizhou and Shanghai . Media playback is supported on this device Subscribe to the BBC Sport newsletter to get our pick of news , features and video sent to your inbox .", "Nama sold its Northern Ireland portfolio to Cerberus , a US investment fund , in 2014 . The Irish Times has reported that the Comptroller and Auditor General ( C & AG ) will say that failings in the sales process could have resulted in \" hundred of millions of euro \" being realised . Nama , an state agency , was established in 2009 to take control of billions of euro of property loans which were damaging the banks . Controversy around the sales process has centred on the role of the businessman and Nama advisor Frank Cushnahan . While working as an advisor to Nama he began talking to a US investment fund , Pimco , which was in buying the portfolio . He left his Nama role and went to assist the fund with its bid . He was to be paid \u00a3 5m if the bid succeeded - but it collapsed Nama learned of Mr Cushnahan 's role . two firms made offers to buy the Northern Ireland portfolio . The bid of \u00a3 1.24bn - a fraction above the reserve price - was made by Cerberus . The move comes amid renewed demand for plastic records , which occupy a market niche . At one time , the format had been expected to disappear after the rise of CDs , downloads and streaming . During vinyl 's decline from the 1980s , vinyl record factories closed down , with production confined to a firms . But this year , vinyl revenue is expected to hit $ 1bn ( \u00c2 \u00a3 770m ) , with consumers swearing by its sound quality . Analysis : Jonty Bloom , business correspondent They said the CD had killed it and that downloads had left it and buried : but vinyl is . Sony , which played a part in killing off vinyl by developing CDs , has seen them replaced in turn by music technology as downloads and streaming , but vinyl is . The format has been saved by a resurgence in demand , as it attracts consumers , but generations who have rediscovered records , in clubs and at music festivals . Sony is struggling to find engineers who know to make records . Part of the reason for the popularity of vinyl records may be that you can sell them in shops . In the UK , record sales brought in money year than streaming platforms - although the unit costs of vinyl is times that of streaming . Vinyl records have been growing in popularity in years , boosted by events as Record Store Day in April every year , for which record companies produce singles and albums . Sony 's move comes a months after it equipped its Tokyo studio with a cutting lathe , used to produce the master discs needed for manufacturing vinyl records . It has said which titles it will be pressing in vinyl , but sellers in the format these days are a mixture of back-catalogue items and releases by bands .", "Victoria mated with a bear at the Highland Wildlife Park at Kincraig , near Aviemore , this year . The nutrient keeps bones , and protects against conditions like osteoporosis . The guidance was drawn up because it is thought fears about skin cancer have made people about being in the sun . Cancer Research UK and the National Osteoporosis Society are among the bodies which agree that \" and \" spells in summer sunshine times a week can benefit your health . The experts say it is to go in sun in the middle of the day , as you cover up or apply sunscreen before your skin goes . Professor Rona Mackie , from the British Association of Dermatologists , said : \" sun protection with factor suncream on all the time is , in terms of vitamin D levels . \" Australia has changed its policy on this . They 're producing charts showing parts of Australia sun protection may be required during some parts of the year . \" Some of the messages about sun exposure have been . UK summer sunshine is . We do have days in the year it is . \" What 's changed is that we 're saying that exposure of 10 to 15 minutes to the UK summer sun , without suncream , times a week is a balance between vitamin D levels and any risk of skin cancer . \" government advice recommends vitamin D supplements for women and children aged under five . But the experts who wrote the statement say mothers are made of this recommendation . They suggest women consult their GP . Winter levels of vitamin D can be helped by a break in the sun - or by eating fish , liver and margarine . Cancer Research UK 's clinician , Professor Peter Johnson , said : \" A diet and sun exposure will be for the majority of the UK population to minimise their cancer risk . \" The area of vitamin D and cancer is . \" There 's some evidence , which is in bowel cancer , that levels of vitamin D in the blood correlate with the risk of developing cancer . \" But that does mean those levels cause bowel cancer . \" We think that levels of vitamin D are to be contributors to the chances of developing cancer in the UK population . \" The statement highlighted questions about vitamin D that warrant research . The committee , headed by Conservative MP Bernard Jenkin , said the purdah probe would form the part of a inquiry into the EU Referendum Bill , the proposed law that will authorise a referendum on the UK 's membership of the EU by the end of 2017 . Mr Jenkin said he and his colleagues wanted to know the government was planning to \" disapply \" the existing rules on government announcements in the four weeks leading up to the referendum . The inquiry will focus on the existing rules , as set out in the 2000 Political Parties and Referendum Act , the government 's case for amending them , ministers plan to go about it and the impact it will have on the impartiality of the service . In a vote on the issue month , 27 MPs rebelled against their party , urging ministers to reinstate the purdah period although the government won the vote after Labour abstained . The government has said the existing rules would prevent ministers from attending EU meetings and making decisions with a dimension . They have insisted they will address MPs' concerns about this and matters - as the funding to sides and the length of the campaign itself - as the bill makes its way through the Commons . Mr Tinley , a Unite officer in the East Midlands , said : \" If you move [ research and development ] , the manufacturing goes with it . \" You could be arguing that the presence of Rolls-Royce is being put at risk . \" I get called a scaremonger for this but I 've sat and looked in the eyes of these people [ management ] , I do see that commitment . \" Dr Ian Jackson , from Staffordshire University 's business school , said turning grants into loans could have a effect on Rolls-Royce . England are to tour Bangladesh to play two Tests and three one-day internationals in October and November 2016 .", "Cryptococcus neoformans is a fungus that can cause a infection in people with systems - those with HIV . Birds are known to carry the fungus , with experts puzzled the birds themselves do appear to become . Research has found a blood cell called a macrophage can block its growth . The fungus , found in bird 's droppings , infects the lungs or the system . Scientists at the University of Sheffield and the University of Birmingham found it can grow within the bird 's tract , but if it tries to invade the bird 's body the system destroys it . Dr Simon Johnston , who led the research , said : \" Birds have a body temperature than humans , but this is to stop the fungus . \" By studying bird cells under the microscope , we have seen that macrophage cells have the ability to block the growth of the fungus , which can be in humans . He added : \" If we can learn some animals are to resist infection we might be to gain insights into we can improve the response to this fungus . \" The universities said the work was part of a effort to help fight cryptococcosis . The findings are reported in the journal Scientific Reports .", "The flight from Manchester Airport to Agadir in Morocco , was diverted to London Gatwick than an hour after take-off on Thursday . The FBI was talking to both Apple and Google about its fears , said Mr Comey . The conversations with tech firms needed to be had before the day police forces lost access to those devices , he said . \" I 'd hate to have people look at me and say , ' Well come you ca save this kid ? ' ' come you ca do this thing ?'\" said Mr Comey in a briefing . His comments came in reaction to a decision by Apple to enable a file encryption system on its iOS 8 software for which it has no keys . This means it would be to comply with any request to help police get at the data on those devices . Google has said it is planning to enable a encryption system by default on the version of Android . Investigators from 21 countries gathered at Interpol 's headquarters in France in October to share information on suspects involved in a range of crimes involving the environment . Called Operation Infra Terra , the agency is asking for assistance from the public in tracking down nine suspects . \" the detail , which you might think is , has the potential to break a case combined with evidence the police have ,\" said Ioannis Kokkinis , from Interpol . \" all it takes is a pair of eyes to bring momentum to an investigation and provide the missing clue which will help locate these wanted individuals , some of whom have been evading justice for years ,\" he added . One of those named is Feisal Mohammed Ali , alleged to be the leader of an ivory smuggling ring in Kenya . He is being sought in connection with the seizure of 314 pieces , weighing over two tonnes in Mombasa in June . Others on the list include Ahmed Kamran who was charged with an attempt to smuggle over 100 animals , including giraffes and impalas , to Qatar on a plane . Ariel Bustamante Sanchez is alleged to have been involved in tuna fishing in protected waters off Costa Rica . The move has been welcomed by Convention on the International Trade in Endangered Species ( Cites ) . They are concerned with the impact of crime on species but with the effect on stability . \" Countries are treating wildlife crime as a offence , and we will leave no stone to locate and arrest these criminals to ensure that they are brought to justice ,\" said Ben Janse van Rensburg from Cites . \" The public can play a role in this effort , they our eyes and ears on the ground . Their support can help ensure that the offenders face the might of the law and are punished . \" Member of the public who have any information on the location of the fugitives can use this form to contact Interpol . Information can be given to any crime stoppers programme . Khalid Sheikh Mohammed is accused of masterminding the attacks while the others are implicated for providing support for the co-ordinated hijacking . In May , a hearing in the case lasted 13 hours . During that hearing , which charged the five men , the defendants made outbursts and refused to answer the judge 's questions or use the translation system . In addition to Khalid Sheikh Mohammed , defendants Ramzi Binalshibh , Mustafa Ahmad al-Hawsawi , Ali Abd al-Aziz Ali and Waleed bin Attash are being prosecuted in a tribunal for wartime offences known as a commission . They are charged with conspiring with al-Qaeda , terrorism , and one count of murder for each known victim of the 11 September attacks at the time the charges were filed - 2,976 in total . The five face a death penalty sentence if convicted . CIA waterboarding tapes revealed On Monday , the defendants listened and answered the judge 's questions , although Khalid Sheikh Mohammed said : \" I do think there 's any justice in this court . \" Defence lawyers argued during the hearing that their clients should be forced to attend the rest of the week 's hearings , because the transport from their cells may remind them of their time at CIA prisons . Before their transfer to the US base at Guantanamo Bay in 2006 , the defendants were held for years in CIA prisons . All five have said they were tortured during interrogations . Khalid Sheikh Mohammed was water-boarded before being brought to Guantanamo . \" We have to talk about torture ,\" Air Force Captain Michael Schwartz , a defence lawyer , said on Monday . But Judge James Pohl said the issue was at this stage . Prosecution lawyers have said the use of waterboarding and methods could be determining whether statements were given . The court is expected to hear a defence request to abolish what they term a \" classification \" that treats any discussion of the CIA prisons as secret , as a media request to limit closing of the courtroom for sessions . Judge Pohl ruled that the defendants would be forced to attend hearings scheduled to run through the end of this week , but did rule out hearings . It was stationed in Cornwall , Hampshire , Norfolk and Shropshire during the war but crashed in 1944 . Bidding stalled below its \u00c2 \u00a3 120,000 to \u00c2 \u00a3 150,000 valuation . The aircraft saw service with four RAF squadrons between 1941 and 1944 and was flown by author Alec Lumsden , who gave it the name Bette and added a character from the Daily Mirror cartoon strip ' Jake ' to the paint work . After it crashed in Shropshire in September 1944 , killing its pilot , its wreckage was taken to Ibsley museum , Ringwood , Hampshire and displayed . The aircraft was passed to a collector who showed it at events . It has been immortalised by modelmakers Airfix and Revell . John Tomlin , from Historics at Brooklands , said : \" The side of war birds is an market . There are 42 flying Spitfires and this seems to be increasing year . \" The rarity , the history and the provenance of all these aircraft make them items and they 're investments that can be used and enjoyed by a lot of people . \" Experts believe it would cost \u00c2 \u00a3 1.8m to restore the plane .", "The boar - which has a moving head - is one of a number of replica creatures at Mountfitchet Castle . In the UK , an act of Parliament passed in 1928 allowed for Easter Sunday to be fixed on the Sunday after the Saturday in April . , this has been activated and Easter has remained , determined by the moon 's cycle . Easter is the festival , as it celebrates the resurrection of Jesus Christ following his death by crucifixion on Good Friday . The archbishop said he was in talks with Pope Francis , leader Pope Tawadros , and the leader of the Orthodox church Patriarch Bartholomew . Mr Welby said he hoped the change would happen \" in between five and 10 years time \" . \" I would love to see it before I retired \" , he said , although he warned the attempt to make such a change was in the Century . An source told the BBC there had been 15 attempts to agree a date since . Easter is on the Sunday after the moon following the spring equinox , meaning it can be celebrated on a Sunday between 22 March and 25 April . But the Orthodox church follows the Julian calendar , has Easter celebrations compared with those of Western Christianity . In 1990 , the Vatican approved a proposal for a fixed date , which was to agreement with churches and governments . The scheme aims to reduce opposition to energy development . It has been developed by the industry alongside community groups . The Shared Ownership Taskforce plan follows programmes in Denmark which have been running for than two decades . It applies to anything entering the planning system from Monday . than 70 % of people in the UK say they like wind farms , according to a government survey . , proximity provokes a response and the wind farms are considered a blot on the landscape . The government insisted that wind farm developers should give communities \u00c2 \u00a3 5,000 a year for every megawatt of energy installed - to support initiatives . The taskforce goes by insisting that any applications entering the planning system must offer to sell part of their business to locals - between 5 and 25 % . This can be in the form of shares , crowd-funding or debentures . Nina Skorupska , Chief Executive , Renewable Energy Association welcomes the plan . She told BBC News : \" in Europe this is , so we 're the UK is working towards this vision of a energy market . \" The scheme has been promoted by the Energy and Climate Change Secretary , Edward Davey . He said : \" Community energy is revolutionising energy development in the UK , and shared ownership will offer people the opportunity to buy in to the energy that their communities are producing . \" The Vice-Chair of the Taskforce and an associate of Co-operatives UK , Rebecca Willis , said : \" We know from our experience at grass roots level that there 's a appetite among communities to invest in energy . \" There are , , to be areas people will prefer to keep their view than to cash in a dividend cheque . groups facing gas developments in their area may regard the renewables scheme with interest . The duchy said warning signs were put up in 2016 and it planned to \" see what can be done \" . on this story , and Devon and Cornwall news The duchy was involved in a series of meetings and concluded there was no \" solution \" as the area had protected status , and that re-engineering the course of a river was a and process with no guarantees of success . The council said the beach had become since a breakwater was damaged by storms in 2015 , causing the River Gannel to change course . this month 11 bodyboarders had to be rescued at the beach . The council said : \" Since the river diverted , movements of sand have occurred that have made bathing conditions at states of tide and sea condition \" . The council met the , the National Trust and the Marine Management Organisation on 27 January to discuss the issue but no repairs were authorised . Floodwater is threatening parts of Austria and the Czech Republic . At 13 people have died and two are missing as a result of the floods . Rising waters have been triggered by rain following a spring . Eight deaths were recorded in the Czech Republic and three in Germany , while two people were reported and two in Austria , according to a European Commission update on Tuesday evening . Parts of Germany have seen flooding in centuries . , in the Czech Republic , the water level has stabilised in the capital Prague , there had been fears of a repeat of disasters in 2002 and 1997 . Helicopters started removing residents from their homes in Deggendorf on Wednesday after two levees along the Danube and Isar rivers broke . Firefighter Alois Schraufstetter said the floodwater in the town was 3m ( 9.8ft ) . \" This is a situation ,\" he was quoted as saying by Germany 's DPA news agency . Four farmers were rescued at the minute by a helicopter before their tractor was submerged , he added . newspapers said water levels in the city of Halle were at their for four centuries . Officials said the city was in danger after floodwaters from the Saale river damaged a section of dykes . The level of the River Elbe in the city of Dresden , 600 people were evacuated , is expected to peak until Thursday morning . Coaches ferried people out the town of Muhlberg , 40km ( 25 miles ) of Dresden , as thousands were told to leave on Wednesday afternoon . And it turns out to be a fort at Slack , on the outskirts of Huddersfield in West Yorkshire . Prof Peter Field , a expert in literature , said : \" It was by chance . I was looking at some maps , and all the ducks lined up . \" I believe I may have solved a mystery . \" guesses for the location of the round table include Caerleon in Newport , Somerset 's Cadbury Castle , and Tintagel in Cornwall . In Roman times , Slack was home to a fort called Camulodunum , which means \" the fort of the god Camul \" . Over the years , processes would have reduced Camulodunum to Camelot . Though and today , and though it was abandoned and dilapidated by the time of King Arthur around A.D . 500 , Prof Field argues that this site at Slack would have been considered a stronghold . At that time , Britons , who could have been led by King Arthur , held the north and the coast against the invading Anglo-Saxons . Slack , on the road from Chester to York , would have been the location from which to defend the coast . Prof Field added : \" If there was a King Arthur , he will have lived around AD500 , although the mention of him in Camelot is in a poem from the Champagne region of France from 1180 . \" There is no mention of Camelot in the period between those dates , known as the Dark Ages , the country was at war , and was recorded . \" In this gap , people passed on information , got lost in transmission , and people may have made up facts or messed up known information . \" Prof Field , who taught at Bangor from 1964 to 2004 , has been researching the location of Camelot for the 18 months . He spoke about his findings during the launch of Bangor University 's Stephen Colclough centre for the history and culture of the book .", "Vardy , 29 , has scored for the champions since 10 September - a run of 14 games - but netted in England 's 2-2 friendly draw with Spain week . They were dropped off at Nant Peris while the MRT walked down the peak .", "The Home Office decided to halt the Detained Fast Track ( DFT ) system amid concerns over safeguards , for \" applicants \" . Immigration minister James Brokenshire said he hoped the DFT system would resume within weeks . It is thought about 800 applicants are affected - and can seek bail . Of those , it is estimated that 100 may have to be released . The system , introduced in 2000 , accelerates hearings and appeals while keeping the individual detained . It is used in cases which officials believe can be decided . month the Court of Appeal ordered the Home Office to halt the system after an High Court hearing concluded it contained \" unfairness \" . High Court judge Mr Justice Nicol put a \" stay \" - a delay - on his ruling on 12 June , following a case brought by campaign group Detention Action . This meant the system remained in operation until the government had exhausted all opportunities to appeal . BBC home affairs correspondent Danny Shaw said officials were worried their procedures were as they should be . In a statement to the House of Commons , Mr Brokenshire said the system had \" come under challenge \" . \" Risks surrounding the safeguards within the system for applicants have been identified to the extent that we cannot be of the level of risk of unfairness to applicants who may enter DFT . \" In light of these issues , I have decided to suspend the operation of the detained policy . \" I hope this pause to be in duration , a matter of weeks , but I will resume operation of this policy I am the structures are in place to minimise any risk of unfairness . \" The decision to suspend the process means those asylum seekers detained and awaiting hearings will be reassessed at a \" level \" to see if they can be released from detention to continue their asylum application in the way . Mr Brokenshire added : \" Those who meet the criteria for detention will be affected by the decision to suspend DFT . \" are detained under these powers , for example because they are at risk of absconding and face removal . \" if detention can be justified outside a DFT process will applicants be released to continue their asylum claim in the asylum system . \" He said applicants who face removal to a country , pose a risk to the public or are offenders are \" to be detained or remain detained \" . The DFT system accelerated some 4,300 asylum applications or decisions in 2013 . It processes 30 to 40 cases a week .", "Aamir Siddiqi , 17 , was stabbed at his home in Roath in 2010 and two men , Jason Richards and Ben Hope , were jailed for life in 2013 . The resolution would be and cannot pass into law . There will be no penalties for using the flag emoji . \" The flag is a design . it 's the flag , who knows , we 're getting into a contest . We go into this weekend knowing that . \" There is no thought of revenge or righting wrongs of the World Cup and , although it 's to forget , it has got to go to the back of our minds . \"", "Katie Milby , 13 , has Morquio A , a syndrome which affects 105 people in the UK . It leads to the deterioration of mobility , health and stamina . Her friend Kyle Pirrie has started a petition seeking to see the medicine Vimizim made on the NHS . There is no known cure to Morquio syndrome but the drug improves the life of people with the condition . It replaces a missing enzyme which allows children to continue to grow , as improving stamina and the ability to walk . It relieves pain . The drug 's manufacturers have been providing the treatment to patients at their expense but they are going to withdraw it unless the NHS in England and Scotland commit to funding it . The Stranraer Academy student said her life would be without the drug . \" I would be to move I 'd be in pain ,\" she said . \" And I would be to go to school . \" It was that situation which prompted her friend to launch the petition which has 2,000 signatures . \" As a friend I suppose I felt that she was going to be denied this because I know she has got a outlook on life ,\" Kyle explained . \" She 's , she 's and I would hate to see her in pain all the time . \" Galloway and West Dumfries MSP Alex Fergusson has backed the petition . \" This is a medication but , as Katie herself asked me , do you put a value on a life ?\" he asked . \" There are over a hundred sufferers throughout the UK , with five in Scotland , and those who have had treatment with Vimizim report a reduction in pain and the symptoms of this syndrome . \" Life expectancy , which exceeds the 20s without treatment , can be extended with this treatment , and it is to the credit of Katie and her friends that they have raised this petition to try to ensure that the treatment is to all . \" The Scottish Medicines Consortium said the drug was going through its assessment process . Four cases led to nine defendants being jailed for 59 offences against 15 girls from Peterborough and in the East Midlands . \" We are with this sentence today as it represents justice for the girls and women who suffered at the hands of this criminal ,\" said Wendi Ogle-Welbourn , from Peterborough City Council . She praised the \" bravery \" of the victims who had given evidence during the course of the trial . \" Their courage in reliving some experiences at the hands of this criminal has enabled us to get the result we did today and means that girls and women are in our city ,\" she said . About 70 personnel will be in Somalia carrying out , and engineering duties . Around 300 troops are be deployed to the conflict in South Sudan . Al-Shabab - the group allied to al-Qaeda - is battling Somalia 's government for control of the country . Who are Somalia 's al-Shabab ? questions for force in Somalia defector : I left al-Shabab The group has carried out a string of attacks - including in Kenya - and is believed to have between 7,000 and 9,000 fighters . The African Union Mission in Somalia ( AMISOM ) was launched in 2007 , and is comprised of troops from Uganda , Burundi , Djibouti , Kenya and Ethiopia . In South Sudan , conflict between government and forces has seen than 2.2 million people flee from their homes in the state , which broke from Sudan in 2011 . The troops being sent to South Sudan will carry out engineering work to strengthen infrastructure . It follows a commitment by UK Prime Minister David Cameron at the UN in New York in September . It formed part of a pledge in the Strategic Defence and Security Review to double the number of UK troops on UN \" \" peacekeeping tasks and support efforts to end some of the world 's destabilising conflicts . Speaking at the time , Mr Cameron said operations \" will help to alleviate and security issues ... helping to bring stability to the region and preventing these challenges from spreading \" . Announcing the arrival of the team in Somalia , Defence Secretary Michael Fallon said : \" This deployment is another demonstration of the flexibility and reach of our forces . \" It showed the UK 's \" determination to tackle terrorism it rears its head \" , he added . The Ministry of Defence said the UK military 's contribution to UN peacekeeping reflects a history of supporting the organisation , including a lasting presence in Cyprus . Britain has been a contributor to UN peacekeeping missions and is the provider of funds . The country 's leading body , the French Council of the Muslim Faith ( CFCM ) , seeks to distance mainstream Islam from attacks . The initiative comes a year after the Charlie Hebdo killings in Paris . gunmen killed 17 people at Paris sites , including the offices of the Charlie Hebdo magazine and a supermarket . Marking the anniversary of the killings , President Francois Hollande unveiled a plaque on Saturday in tribute to one of those who died , policewoman Clarissa Jean-Philippe . France remembered the four hostages killed at the supermarket . France is under a state of emergency after November 's Paris attacks , carried out by gunmen linked to the Islamic State group , which killed 130 people . Hundreds of mosques are taking part in the event , dubbed a \" cup of tea \" . \" The objective is to create a space people can be and meet worshippers and all of our citizens ,\" CFCM President Anouar Kbibech told AFP . He said the CFCM wanted to use the anniversary of the Charlie Hebdo attacks to \" highlight the values of Islam , to set the cliches about links to violence and terrorism \" .", "catches of cod , haddock and plaice have been increased , the government said . Catches of saithe , whiting and herring will be decreased in line with management plans . Talks between the EU and Norway agreed the catch for cod would be 29,189 tonnes , 5 % on 2014 . The increase will give UK fishermen an 542 tonnes and fishermen around 343 tonnes . A 6 % increase in the haddock catch to 40,711 tonnes gives the UK an 3,468 tonnes and fishermen than 2,500 tonnes . Scottish Fisheries Secretary Richard Lochhead said : \" I am there has been an increase in the quota of these stocks for year which is in line with the advice that the stocks are in shape . \" It is the agreement has been reached this year compared to the talks year and will provide certainty for the industry about opportunities in 2015 and avoids any delays to the commencement of fishing in the year . \" There is to be done to prepare for the discard ban which starts to come into force for fish from 2016 . This outcome will help these stocks continue to rebuild year while helping to minimise discards , and should provide a launchpad for establishing the following year 's quota under the ban . \" We look to the December EU fisheries council we will be highlighting that our vessels need to retain the number of days they can go to sea as any cut would be . \" UK Fisheries Minister George Eustice said the agreements were an \" result for the UK \" . He said : \" It sees UK fishermen getting a 5 % increase in their quota for cod - the rise in cod quota in two years . The increase is an sign that we are achieving our goals ; a fishing industry with fish stocks . \" The deal saw a 7 % rise in North Sea haddock and 15 % rise in plaice quotas . A boy and an man from London were arrested , along with a man from Barking . Ch Insp Simon Anslow said none of those who were stabbed suffered injuries . \" This is a situation in any town and we are using the range of tools at our disposal to keep the majority of people , while making those on causing trouble will be picked up and dealt with ,\" he said . \" We will be pursuing a investigation to put all those we can find who are for this behaviour before the courts . \" The use of section 60 of the Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994 gives officers the power to search people for objects and weapons without the need to have a suspicion . The powers were in force in Colchester town centre from 18:40 until 21:50 GMT on Saturday . Read on this and stories on the BBC Essex Live page Colchester MP Will Quince said he supported the force 's use of the powers in this instance . \" Their action in getting the section 60 order , which is a used piece of legislation , means they can stop anybody without cause to check if they have a weapon within a time frame - I applaud the police for doing that ,\" he said .", "The proposed deal would combine the and cable operators in the US . Charter is buying Bright House Networks , another cable operator , for $ 10.4bn . The combined three firms will serve cable television and broadband to 23.9 million customers in 41 states . Charter will pay $ 55bn in cash and stock for Time Warner Cable , with the balance of the $ 78.7bn valuation coming from TWC 's debts . US cable companies are facing competition from service providers as Amazon and Netflix , as customers choose to stream films and television shows over the internet at a time of their convenience . Cable companies are responding by trying to cut costs and improve the quality of their shows . The merged cable giant will compete with US cable market leader Comcast , which has about 27 million customers . Charter 's takeover move comes a month after Comcast abandoned its plan to buy Time Warner Cable fearing pressure from regulators . The deal is to come under scrutiny , and the Federal Communications Commission ( FCC ) issued a statement . \" The FCC reviews every merger on its merits and determines whether it would be in the interest ,\" FCC chairman Tom Wheeler said . \" In applying the interest test , an absence of harm is . The commission will look to see consumers would benefit if the deal were to be approved . \" The merged company would be than Comcast , which serves about a third of US broadband customers , said analyst Craig Moffett of Moffett Nathanson Research . \" One has to be about risks that this deal could be rejected ,\" he added . Liberty Broadband , which owns about a quarter of Charter , is expected to own about 20 % of the company . The deal values Time Warner Cable at $ 195.71 per share .", "The Night Wolves had planned to enter week as part of a ride across Europe to commemorate the anniversary of World War Two . Rising property prices in Australia 's city , Sydney , a currency and a drop in iron ore prices were among the reasons for the cut . Mr Oliver said help would to be required \" in the form of an dollar - and to ensure this happens the RBA may have to cut interest rates into territory . \"", "But the summer visitor is in decline and , according to a study , its habits may be to blame . Scientists have tagged birds leaving the UK and believe they take two routes on their journey to spend the winter in Africa . , survival is on the route via Spain , they report in the journal , Nature Communications . And this suggests that migration - as factors as loss of farmland and food - may be to blame for the cuckoo 's decline . than half of cuckoos in the UK have been lost over the 20 years , according to the British Trust for Ornithology ( BTO ) in Norfolk , which led the research . \" That pattern of starting in the place but taking two routes to get has been seen in any birds , to the of our knowledge ,\" said researcher Dr Chris Hewson . \" We need to understand the cycle of a bird in order to understand its population decline . \" Facts about the cuckoo Source : British Library / RSPB / BTO Since 2011 , the BTO has been satellite-tracking cuckoos to study their migration patterns they leave the UK . Working with the University of Copenhagen , the research institute used satellite tags to track 42 cuckoos from the UK population during than 50 autumn migrations . The researchers found that birds from declining populations were to migrate to winter breeding grounds in Africa along a route ( through Spain ) than along an route ( via Italy and the Balkans ) . The mortality occurred before reaching the environment of the Sahara desert , despite the fact that the route is a tenth at this point . The scientists think birds may have encountered drought conditions in Spain . , they may have been deprived of insect food as caterpillars before leaving the UK , leaving them with fat stores for their journey . bird species are threatened around the world due to factors including climate change , habitat change and habitat loss . birds ' lack world protection ' Understanding mortality occurs during their cycles is , for land birds , which show some of the population declines , say the scientists . The border between the two countries runs up the mountain near its peak . But Prime Minister Erna Solberg said that she had had to turn down the idea because the country 's constitution prohibited any sacrifice of territory . Part of Halti mountain is in Finland - and forms its point - but the peak is 20m ( 66ft ) across the border inside territory . Campaigners had proposed moving the border to give the summit , at 1,330m ( 4,363 ft ) , to Finland , saying the change would be on the map . The sculptures will be created in Andover , Hampshire , before moving to the Arboretum in Alrewas - the UK 's site of remembrance .", "John Coyle tried to rob a Scotmid store in Glasgow 's Easterhouse , but left after the worker shouted to her mother who worked . They were buried eight inches beneath the soil on a farm near Banbridge . Experts believe they are part of a hoard of coins found by Mr Crawford in the field in 2001 . The collection was dispersed over time through ploughing . This was Mr Crawford 's time at a treasure trove inquest . He said his success was about \" knowing to go \" and \" having a idea of to look \" . \" There is chance of finding something you know people would have been living 1,000 years ,\" he added . He said discovering artefacts was a \" \" feeling . \" It 's the money , it 's the fact that you are the person to touch something in 700 years ,\" he said . \" I found a bronze axe 10 years and it 's the idea that something has been hidden for and you get to see it and touch it . \" curator at the Ulster Museum , Robert Heslip , said the hoard of coins was buried near a landmark - a Rath ring fort . The person who left them may have died before reclaiming them . He said finds like this one are because they are to a time and to this part of Northern Ireland . \" You find nothing like this in the south of Ireland and they peter out in the west ,\" he said . \" There have been a cluster of these sorts of finds in Ulster . \" The coins will be sent to the British Museum in London for valuation . Kentucky Methodist Hospital information systems director Jamie Reid named the malware involved as Locky , a bug that encrypts files , documents and images and renames them with the extension . . The way Locky gets itself on machines is via a spam email with an attached document that looks like nonsense and advises readers to enable macros \" if the data encoding is \" . Once the malware is downloaded , it sends a message to desktops with instructions about users can pay to have files unlocked . Croydon Clinical Commissioning Group ( CCG ) said the plan could save the NHS thousands of pounds per year . Mother Sarah Rose said it was \" like taking milk from a baby \" as her son Sam depended on it . Richmond Clinical Commissioning Group is consulting about withdrawing formula prescriptions and the consultation runs until 3 February . It said : \" It is proposed that GPs provide infant formula milk , thickened formulas or formulas for intolerance on prescription as these are to buy from community pharmacies and supermarkets at a cost to formula . \" People who might be affected include those with cow 's milk protein allergy and reflux disease , it warned , but it calculated this would provide a saving of \u00a3 386,000 per year . formula milk costs about \u00a3 10 for a week 's supply and is in supermarkets and chemists . Miss Rose , a school support assistant and mother-of-two , said Sam had a prescription for the formula that would cost \u00a3 40 for one tin that would feed him for two and half days . She said : \" The tins are half the size of milk formula so it works out at eight times the price . \" \" We have got a lot of money . This is me being , but it 's like taking milk from a baby \" , she said . \" We went to A & E before he [ Sam ] was diagnosed with this allergy at four months . He was screaming in pain all the time . He arched his back and started refusing milk . he 's a baby . I do want to go to that . \" An petition calling on the CCG to reverse its decision has attracted than 6,000 signatures and charities , as Allergy UK and Anaphylaxis Campaign , expressed their disappointment and urged a rethink . Dr Tony Brzezicki , Clinical Chair of NHS Croydon CCG said : \" We share the public 's concerns and we will do what we can to reduce the impact on the in our communities and to make funding is for those with the need . \" He said the prescriptions would cease in the coming months and families would be given notice of the plans before the change took effect . \" These are decisions but we need to focus our resources we can have the impact on people 's health and well-being ,\" he added .", "Vithiya Alphons , 24 , has myeloid leukaemia but her Sri Lankan background makes the search as people are on donor registers . Christine Ohuruogu , Kelly Sotherton , Marilyn Okoro and Nicola Sanders finished the race but have moved up to as a result of both Russia and Belarus being disqualified due to failed tests . The men 's Beijing medals are in the possession of the British Olympic Association and British Athletics but an announcement is to be made on they will be awarded . They could be presented at month 's Diamond League Anniversary Games , or at the World Championships in London in August . But , as the World Championships is an IAAF event , the IOC would have to give permission for any presentation to take place as Olympic medals fall under their jurisdiction . British Athletics does have possession of medals for the women 's 4x400m team as proceedings are regarding athletes in their race . Britons Dame Jessica Ennis-Hill , Jo Pavey , Sotherton and Goldie Sayers are among those waiting to receive Olympic and World Championship medals they were denied by drugs cheats . Sayers has told the Guardian she would be \" \" if she did receive her medal at the World Championships this summer .", "People with a DNA variation in a gene called PDSS2 tend to drink cups of coffee , a study carried out at the University of Edinburgh has found . It suggests the gene reduces cell ability to break down caffeine . This causes it to stay in the body for and means those with the gene get the caffeine hit through coffee . One scientist working on the project said it suggests the \" drive to drink coffee may be embedded in our genes \" . The researchers studied the DNA of 370 people living in a village in Italy and 843 people from six villages in Italy . The subjects were asked to complete a survey including a question about cups of coffee they drank each day . The team found people with the PDSS2 DNA variation tended to consume cups of coffee than people without the variation - to one cup on . Researchers replicated the study in a group of 1,731 people from the Netherlands . The result was but the effect of the gene on the number of cups of coffee consumed was . The scientists said the change could be to the styles of coffee in the two countries . In Italy , people tend to drink cups as espresso whereas in the Netherlands the preference is towards cups which contain caffeine . Dr Nicola Pirastu , a Chancellor 's Fellow at the University of Edinburgh , said : \" The results of our study add to existing research suggesting that our drive to drink coffee may be embedded in our genes . \" We need to do studies to confirm the discovery and to clarify the link between PDSS2 and coffee consumption . \" The study is published in the journal Scientific Reports and was conducted at the universities of Edinburgh and Trieste , the Burlo Garofolo Pediatric Institute in Italy , the Erasmus Medical Centre and PolyOmica , a data analysis company based in Groningen , the Netherlands .", "Its parliament approved the sending of a invitation , which he has to accept before ascending to the throne . The revered King Bhumibol Adulyadej died on 13 October , plunging Thailand into mourning . The prince was expected to succeed his father , but officials had said he wanted to postpone it by at a year . The reason given was that he wanted to give the people time to mourn his father before he became king . Correspondents say Thailand was left in an limbo as the prince , the heir , should have succeeded his father . In the doubts have been expressed by officials over the crown prince can perform the role played by his father for 70 years . The monarchy occupies a place in Thailand 's order . King Bhumibol Adulyadej had been seen as a unifying figure amid periods of unrest , including during the coup in 2014 . The leader of Thailand 's parliament , the National Legislative Assembly , is expected to meet the crown prince in the days to invite him . Once the crown prince accepts , his succession would be announced to the public . But it is that will happen . Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda is standing in as regent . Thailand has had what might be called successions . The was 70 years , the King Ananda was found shot in his bedroom in circumstances . he died , an emergency session of parliament that night named his brother Bhumibol king . Despite speculation over the prospects of his sister Princess Sirindhorn , Crown Prince Vajiralongkorn has been the heir to the throne since his investiture in 1972 . Thai succession law follows the principle of primogeniture , the throne should pass to the son of the reigning king , but it gives the king the discretion to name his choice . King Bhumibol wavered in his endorsement of the crown prince . But the crown prince 's decision to delay taking the throne has made this another succession which has departed from the script . His reasons are known ; mourning for his father would have been affected had he been anointed after his father 's death .", "The East Antrim MP had been considering putting his name after Nigel Dodds ruled himself out . But the year marked an milestone - 22 - he broke the 800m , one mile and 1,500m world records within the space of 41 days . He was the person to hold all three records at the time . He won Sports Personality of the Year . 1980 - First Olympic medals Coe will be remembered for his Olympic success . In 1980 , amid rivalry with runner Steve Ovett , he won gold in the 1,500m in Moscow . He took silver in his race - the 800m - finishing to Ovett . 1984 - Second Olympic Gold Despite spending months fighting illness , Coe returned to the Olympic track in Los Angeles four years and became the man to win 1,500m golds , beating Briton Steve Cram into ( Ovett failed to finish the race ) . Coe was beaten into in the 800m by Joaquim Cruz . 1992 - Enters Parliament After retiring from athletics in 1990 , Coe pursued a career in politics and was chosen to fight the Falmouth and Camborne constituency for the Conservatives at the 1992 election . Coe beat the Liberal Democrat candidate by than 3,000 votes and took his place in Parliament . He lost the seat in 1997 Tony Blair 's Labour Party swept to power . He returned to politics as chief of staff to William Hague , he was Leader of the Opposition . 2005 - Helps secure Olympics for London Despite London lagging in place behind Paris and Madrid in stages , the UK capital secured the games under Coe 's leadership . Sports commentators said a speech he made , before the vote , helped turn the race in London 's favour . \" This is on a planet to winning the gold medals ,\" Coe said at the time . He went to become Chairman of the London Organising Committee of the Olympic and Paralympic Games and is said to have been a player in organising the Queen 's appearance in the James Bond scene in the Games' opening ceremony . 2015 - Elected president of the IAAF Despite one of the CVs in athletics history , Lord Coe suggested his election as IAAF chief topped all his achievements . He beat Sergey Bubka , a Olympic pole vault champion , by 115 votes to 92 . Activists said the block moved Turkey 's censorship policies from \" \" to \" \" . Tor , known as The Onion Router , aims to conceal people go by using encryption and bouncing requests for webpages through a network of computers . The system has become in nations , as China and Turkey , governments are known to watch what people do and say . Turkey Blocks , which monitors internet censorship in the nation , said its monitoring of Tor showed that it was being blocked across the country . The organisation started to investigate after people in Turkey reported having problems reaching the Tor network . It added that the government had put in place systems at ISPs to spot people were trying to connect to Tor . These inspect packets of data and can pick out the signature of those that are destined for Tor . Turkey Blocks said the government ordered firms to start blocking VPNs and Tor in December , and has increased the pressure on firms to act by asking for updates about the success of the measures . The monitoring group said that while access to Tor was working , people were reporting that they could access the network if they used a bridge . These are entry points to the Tor network which , because they are listed in the software itself , can survive blocks are imposed . Turkey has a history of cutting off access to websites and services - during periods of unrest .", "The Uruguayan , 25 , was signed from Nacional two years but made six league appearances for Boro , three of them as a substitute . The building opened in 1865 as a hotel , but was bought by a group of philanthropists who founded the university . It is home to departments and is used for teaching . The university said the Old College was one of examples of the work of revival architect John Pollard Seddon . It is one of the town 's buildings with spires , towers , parapets and roofs \" like a French Renaissance chateau \" . Plans include creating a \" quarter \" based around the Old College , a centre providing teaching , learning and study spaces , an art gallery , and lecturing and performance facilities . University vice-chancellor Prof April McMahon said : \" Research shows that Aberystwyth University is recognised as one of the locations to study for undergraduates . \" We want to build on that and develop a world class centre . \" , the Old College should have a community focus as an one . \" We want to provide a resource for residents and visitors as students and staff . \" Our vision is for learning facilities , exhibition space , a university shop and a point of contact for businesses - bringing the town and gown in a quarter . \" Regeneration Minister Huw Lewis said : \" The Old College is an building in Aberystwyth and resonates with and students of the university . \" Its location in the centre of the town can provide a point to the area 's regeneration and the ideas put sound . \" The feasibility study , which will include a number of university properties , is expected to be finished in March 2013 . It will be funded by a government regeneration fund and the university . Its oil industry has been hit by prices , according to the Nigerian Bureau of Statistics ( NBS ) . But the government says there has been growth in sectors . oil sales account for 70 % of government income . The price of oil has fallen from highs of $ 112 a barrel in 2014 to below $ 50 at the moment . Outside the oil industry , the figures show the fall in the currency , the naira , has hurt the economy . It was allowed to float in June to help kick-start the economy , but critics argued it should have been done . The government , , has found some news in the figures . \" There was growth in the and minerals sectors ... the areas in which the government has placed priority ,\" said adviser Adeyemi Dipeolu . Nigeria , which vies with South Africa for the mantle of Africa 's economy , is battling an inflation rate at an high of 17.1 % in July . \" A lot of Nigeria 's predicament could have been avoided ,\" said Kevin Daly from Aberdeen Asset Management . \" The country is on oil because its leaders have diversified the economy . \" , they have tried , and failed , to prop up the naira , which has had a effect on the country 's exchange reserves and any reputation it might have had of being . \" This recession comes as no surprise to millions of Nigerians . say they 've known it . The slump in oil prices has hit Nigeria . The government depends on oil sales for 70 % of its revenues . But critics say government policies made a situation . The decision to delay devaluing Nigeria 's currency meant businesses struggled to get currency to pay for imports , which had a cooling effect on the economy . Following pressure , the government changed tack this summer , allowing the naira to float . That 's led to a spike in inflation , but the hope is that it will attract investors . The government says the country needs to import : it wants to see products made in Nigeria .", "Mining , energy , and stocks were among the gainers , with healthcare and telecoms among the losers . The in line to the throne and king turns one on 22 July . The design of the silver piece was approved by his parents ; his great-grandmother the Queen ; and Chancellor George Osborne . It bears the arms and the year 2014 . Prince George was photographed at the weekend walking with the help of his mother . Shane Bissett , director of coin and bullion at the Royal Mint , said : \" We felt there could be no design to mark the birthday of our king than the arms - the arms of the monarch - minted in honour of the heir to the throne . \" The choice of a coin is , as the metal is associated with babies ... \" Crossing the palm of a baby with silver is a way to wish them wealth and health throughout their life , whilst the \u00a3 5 coin is a favourite for celebrations . \" The coins will be a mintage of 7,500 and will cost \u00a3 80 each from the Royal Mint . The arms incorporates the four quarterings of the arms , each contained in a shield , as a rose , thistle , leek , a sprig of shamrock and a crown . It was created for the Queen and was used on a coin struck for the British Exhibition in New York in 1960 . George 's birth and his christening were marked with coins .", ", the 2018 event , set to showcase art , design and innovation , will be the in the region . Media playback is supported on this device Subscribe to the BBC Sport newsletter to get our pick of news , features and video sent to your inbox .", "The \" witches' marks \" were carved near entrances to buildings , including the house Shakespeare was born and the Tower of London . The symbols were believed to offer protection belief in witchcraft and the supernatural was . But heritage agency Historic England says is known about them . This Halloween it is calling for people to document the marks , which can be found in houses , churches and buildings , from around 1550 to 1750 . The symbols , which were intended to protect inhabitants and visitors of buildings from witches and spirits , took forms , including patterns and letters . The type was the \" Daisy Wheel \" , which looked like a flower drawn with a compass in a line that was supposed to confuse and entrap spirits . They took the form of letters , as AM for Ave Maria , M for Mary or VV , for Virgin of Virgins , scratched into walls , engraved on beams and etched into plasterwork to evoke the power of the Virgin Mary . Known examples include found at Shakespeare 's birthplace in Stratford-upon-Avon , Warwickshire , carved near the cellar door beer was kept , and at the Tithe Barn , Bradford-on-Avon , Wiltshire , to protect crops . Others have been found in caves , as the Witches' Chimney at Wookey Hole , Somerset , which has markings . Duncan Wilson , executive of Historic England , said : \" Witches' marks are a reminder of our ancestors saw the world . \" They fire the imagination and can teach us about beliefs and rituals . \" Ritual marks were cut , scratched or carved into our homes and churches in the hope of making the world a , place . \" They were such a part of life that they were and because they are to overlook , the recorded evidence we hold about they appear and what form they take is . \"", "It came the day after the remains of the boiler house were demolished and the search resumed for three men killed the building came down . , site owner RWE NPower reassured people the tower was standing and had been shrouded in fog . He was speaking to the BBC 's Inside Business programme about growing Northern Ireland 's tourism industry . Mr Husbands took on the job at Titanic Belfast a months before the centre opened in 2012 . In its year of operation , than 800,000 people from 128 countries toured the east Belfast building - double the number it was expected to achieve . Titanic Belfast welcomed its one millionth visitor in July 2013 . Mr Husbands has a wealth of experience in event management , spending 15 years in charge of Belfast 's Waterfront Hall . He managed the Ulster Hall and help to stage a number of events in the city , including the Tall Ships festival in 2009 . In 2014 , he was awarded an MBE from the Queen for services to development and tourism . The PSNI investigation has found none of the men featured \" admitted any act or being involved in any of the incidents portrayed \" . In a statement , the PSNI said : \" Detectives from Serious Crime Branch have studied the contents of a BBC Panorama programme broadcast year into the activities of the MRF . \" Although there does appear to be any admission to criminality by individuals featured in the programme , it will form part of an HET review into all deaths linked to soldiers . \" This review will begin HET resumes its work in the future . \" The unit was disbanded in 1973 , after 18 months . The plain-clothes soldiers carried out patrols in Belfast in cars . Three members of the unit talked to Panorama . They said they had been tasked with \" hunting down \" IRA members in Belfast . asked if on occasion the MRF would make an assumption that someone had a weapon , if they could see one , one of the soldiers replied \" \" . \" We did go around town blasting , shooting over the place like you see on the TV , we were going and finding , looking for our targets , finding them and taking them down ,\" he said . \" We may have seen a weapon , but than would have been weapons in a vigilante patrol . \" One of the soldiers said they were \" to act like an army unit , we were to act like a terror group \" . Llandudno , which is 695m ( 2,280ft ) , is the pier with listed building status meaning any owners would require Listed Building Consent to make changes to the structure . Known as the \" Queen of Welsh Piers \" , it nestles in the crescent bay between the outcrops of the Little and Great Orme . Blackpool Central Pier , which stands at 341m ( 1,118ft ) , and Blackpool South Pier , which is 150m ( 492ft ) , do benefit from listed status , despite opening in 1864 and 1892 . They are known as monk or monkfish by fishermen in the region . They are threatening to humans , living on sand or mud at the bottom of the sea and preying on fish and molluscs . But feeling is fuelling the unrest . By Michael CecireForeign Policy Research Institute The 2014 Sochi Olympics were billed as a way of boosting the economy by bringing tourism to Abkhazia or sourcing materials for construction , but the effect was a source of frustration : the expanded security cordon that penetrated beyond the Russia-Abkhazia border . Some problems can be attributed to the de facto government , but it is Russia that has the power to improve conditions . For example , the building boom in Chechnya has improved conditions ( if rights remain a problem ) , but nothing has happened in Abkhazia . , the opposition 's point of contention is Alexander Ankvab 's ( ) policy towards Georgians in Abkhazia . He has advocated integrating them , granting them \" citizenship \" . The opposition has painted this as a ploy to expand his base and say it could endanger Abkhazia 's identity . Analysis : Unrest in Abkhazia The protesters are led by Raul Khadzhimba , a prime minister and vice-president of Abkhazia , who was defeated by Mr Ankvab in elections in August 2011 . The Black Sea region is recognised as a state by Russia and a countries . It broke from Georgia after a war than 20 years and declared independence in 2008 . Since , it has relied and on Russia . Russia is sending two officials , aide Vladislav Surkov and security council secretary Rashid Nurgaliyev , to Sukhumi in response to the crisis . Opinion among the opposition is said to be divided between those who want Abkhazia to rely on Russia and those who want it to become part of Russia . Mr Ankvab accused the opposition of attempting a coup on Tuesday and said the security forces remained \" to the state \" and were \" taking measures to stabilise the situation \" . Raul Khadzhimba defended the protests , saying : \" Over all the years of his rule the president did allow anybody in his circle to do their work . \" He took upon himself everybody 's responsibilities on their behalf , whether he should or should have been doing this . That led to our country in fact becoming an regime . He the closures would deliver value for money and release land across the UK to build 55,000 homes . Director of listing Roger Bowdler said had to keep their bodies in their homes during the 1800s , \" you 've got the living cheek-by-jowl with the \" . The building used for holding the before funerals , was an example of the facilities proposed by Edwin Chadwick , secretary to the Poor Law Commission , who led a review of conditions . The store addressed people 's fears that their relatives would be buried before they had died . The use of reception houses was phased out with the introduction of undertakers in the 1880s and the building is the survivor of its kind in the capital , according to Historic England . His son , Anthony Johnston , said : \" He had to deal with people dying by the hundreds every day . \" The plaque was unveiled in Northiam , East Sussex Gen Johnston lived . Born in Glasgow , he moved to the village with his family in 1973 . 60 people , including members of Gen Johnston 's family , gathered for the unveiling at the pump house on the village green . Gen Johnston was commanding a unit to the border in April 1945 . He was ordered to move his unit to take charge of the and starving at Bergen-Belsen , which had been liberated by the British . Around 70,000 people had died at the camp in Germany . Mr Johnston said his father had been to talk about his World War Two experiences , due to modesty and wanting to block out such a event . \" There were times in his life inmates , who he had come across at the time , got in touch with him and wanted to acknowledge him ,\" Mr Johnston said . \" than that , he did talk about it . \" In an account which is in the Holocaust Museum in Washington , Gen Johnston wrote : \" did I know that I was to be faced with the test of my career , with a situation that would remain engraved on my memory for the rest of my days . \"[ It ] would instil in me a lasting abhorrence of those who had perpetrated this crime on humanity , but of those who had condoned it . \"", "The device was discovered on Foreglen Road on Wednesday morning following a telephone call to a hospital . The inquest was suspended in September after the CPS carried out a review of the case , concluding it was to bring any charges against Mr Worthington .", "The concept will be known as Vulcan , and it is expected to start operations in 2019 . United Launch Alliance - the venture between Boeing and Lockheed Martin - flies the Atlas and Delta rockets . These are used to loft Nasa science probes , spy satellites and US security missions . In time , both vehicles will be retired as the components come on stream . The element to be introduced will be the booster , which will feature an , engine . This will enable ULA to end its use of RD-180 rocket motors \u2013 something Congress has mandated . Politicians on Capitol Hill dislike the fact that security missions are launched with the aid of propulsion technology . ULA 's preference is to incorporate a methane-oxygen power unit being developed by Blue Origin , the space company run by Amazon entrepreneur Jeff Bezos . the Vulcan booster makes its debut , it will be married to the Centaur upper-stage of the Atlas . But in the 2020s , this will be replaced by a upper-stage that should give the rocket a performance that allows it to exceed the Delta IV Heavy \u2013 the , rocket in the world today , of putting upwards of 25 tonnes in a orbit . , , the Vulcan will be to build and operate . \" A Delta IV Heavy at today \u2019s launch rates costs $ 400m , give or take , depending on the mission and its complexity . I expect the Next Generation Launch System to be than half that ,\" said Tory Bruno , president and CEO of United Launch Alliance . Some cost savings will be made by recovering and reusing the engines on the booster following a flight . The idea is that after separation from the upper-stage , the engines would detach from the tanks and fall to Earth , deploying an shield to protect them from burning up on re-entry into the atmosphere . Parachutes would deploy and a helicopter would swoop to pluck the engines out of the air and return them to the ground for servicing and re-integration into a booster . ULA will say the development programme is costing , but it will run into the billions of dollars . ULA has to modernise , . The priority status it has enjoyed with government contracts is coming to an end , and it is facing competition \u2013 at home , from a SpaceX company , whose rockets are winning favour with Nasa and satellite operators ; and , Europe and Russia are both moving to rocket systems that aim to reduce their launch prices .", "Steven Rodriguez , who was known as A $ AP Yams or Yamborghini , died 26 on 18 January at Brooklyn 's Woodhull Medical Centre . He said : \" There 's no restriction on the imports of these lasers . \"", "The intelligence system - LipNet - watches video of a person speaking and matches the text to the movement of their mouths with 93 % accuracy , the researchers said . Automating the process could help millions , they suggested . But experts said the system needed to be tested in situations . Lip-reading is a business with professionals to decipher what someone is saying up to 60 % of the time . \" Machine lip-readers have potential , with applications in improved hearing aids , dictation in spaces , conversations , speech recognition in environments , identification and processing ,\" wrote the researchers . They said that the AI system was provided with sentences so that it could teach itself which letter corresponded to which lip movement . To train the AI , the team - from Oxford University 's AI lab - fed it 29,000 videos , labelled with the text . Each video was three seconds and followed a pattern . While testers given videos had an error rate of 47.7 % , the AI had one of 6.6 % . The fact that the AI learned from training videos led some on Twitter to criticise the research . Writing in OpenReview , Neil Lawrence pointed out that the videos had \" limited vocabulary and a syntax grammar \" . \" While it 's promising to perform on this data , it 's . While the model may be to read my lips than a human , it can do I say a list of words from a constrained vocabulary in a order ,\" he writes . The project was funded by Google 's intelligence firm DeepMind .", "That the UK is ' ' but ' ' , ' looking ' and a bastion of trade . World Cup winners Lawrence Dallaglio and Jonny Wilkinson were among 12 stars inducted in to the \" hall \" . Members of the public will be to visit from Friday . The World Rugby Hall of Fame was established in 2006 , and absorbed the International Rugby Hall of Fame in 2014 , but has had a home . The attraction , which honours players and administrators who have enhanced the game through achievements , features video archive of rugby matches and memorabilia . The 10 players inducted in the Hall of Fame were England 's Jeremy Guscott and Maggie Alphonsi , Wale 's Shane Williams , John Dawes and Arthur Gould , Scotland 's GPS Macpherson , Ireland 's Brian O'Driscoll , Japan 's Daisuke Ohata , Canada 's Heather Moyes and Australia 's Daniel Carroll . Whatever we do it will have to be under constraints . \"", "was found to have used a tax avoidance scheme called a rate-booster . The court ruled Next diverted UK profits to subsidiaries to claim tax relief on profits . schemes are a way in which firms avoid corporation tax on profits that are paid to the UK parent firm . Under rules designed to prevent taxation of company profits , firms were to claim credit for tax paid on money they made . But some companies were to exploit the rules through the creation of arrangements involving what HM Revenue & Customs ( HMRC ) referred to as \" movements of money between companies in the group , so they can claim there has been taxation \" . Known as rate-booster schemes , this enabled companies to avoid corporation tax by diverting profits made in the UK to subsidiaries . The subsidiary paid tax on those profits - at a rate of corporation tax - before the profits were paid to the UK parent company . , the UK parent company received credits from HMRC for the tax paid by its subsidiary . As a result , companies were to claim tax had been paid on their profits than was the case . changes in 2005 and 2009 mean rate-booster schemes are or , HMRC added . The Next case is the to reach court , following a 2013 ruling against P & O Ferries , although the firm appealed against the decision and an appeal judgement is . HMRC said about \u00a3 130m in tax was at stake across 20 rate-booster cases , which were awaiting the P & O and Next decisions . About 70 rate-boosters have been conceded by companies that wanted to avoid going to court . This has brought in than \u00a3 500m in tax , it added . HMRC 's director general of business tax , Jim Harra , said : \" This case shows HMRC takes action against businesses that try to avoid paying tax through , avoidance schemes . HMRC expects all businesses to steer of schemes . \" In a statement , Next said it had paid the tax owed to HMRC \" some years \" and that this had been accounted for at the time . The retailer described the dispute between itself and HMRC as \" a debate around legislation \" which had been superseded . It added that UK law allowed companies to \" repatriate their profits without a tax charge \" .", "The \" bemusement park \" at a seaside lido in Weston-super-Mare attracted thousands of visitors it opened summer . awards nominees include electronica band Years and Years and the BBC Two adaptation of Wolf Hall .
